Comment: I'm actually very tired of this inspiration argument. I have two huge problems with it.    First in the 2016 primaries we had an inspirational candidate in Bernie and I watched as primary after primary result came in and the turnout was anemic. For all the inspiration there was a 25% decrease in the primary turnout. They rallied, they posted, they engaged on social media, they complained  - but they did not vote. Inspiration wasn't enough to get them to the polls. Instead they spout to this day how they were kept from voting by the DNC, not only is this demonstrably false but a cop out.   Nobody stopped them from voting except themselves. And they were inspired. But it didn't help.    Secondly, we are adults. Needing somebody to inspire us to take care of basic responsibilities is an immature and childish position. Do we need the grocery store owner to inspire us to buy vegetables? Do we need the gym owner to inspire us to work out? And further if a person only works out once or twice every 2 to 4 years, or more likely never at all, do you think they will have strong muscles?  Or more likely weak and ineffective?   Civic engagement is a responsibility. At least for Americans. It is built into our constitution and our culture.   "Of, by and for the people."   The problem is right now we have a good 40%+ chunk of our population that sees no relationship between the government and their day-to-day lives.
Author: Rude-Strawberry-6360

Comment: Very fair critiques. My rebuttal is that while it may be unfortunate that people are so apathetic to going out to vote, that is the current state of affairs. Further, Trump has proven he is able to inspire people to vote. If democrats can’t do the same, then does it really matter how we feel about whether inspiring people to vote is good or bad?  If the goal is winning, then we should do what is needed to win.  edit:   “ Democracy has disappeared in several other great nations--not because the people of those nations disliked democracy, but because they had grown tired of unemployment and insecurity, of seeing their children hungry while they sat helpless in the face of government confusion and government weakness through lack of leadership in government. Finally, in desperation, they chose to sacrifice liberty in the hope of getting something to eat. We in America know that our own democratic institutions can be preserved and made to work. But in order to preserve them we need to act together, to meet the problems of the Nation boldly, and to prove that the practical operation of democratic government is equal to the task of protecting the security of the people.”  -FDR   https://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/documents/fireside-chat-15
Author: LongLiveFDR
